text:
# Door left open

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Play an message on the living room speaker if the garage door has been left open for more than 30 minutes
- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input           | Selector Type | Description                                                                           |
| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | A `binary_sensor` entity selector door sensor that is the target of the automation.   |
| `alert_media`   | `media`       | The target for the `media` selector for the media player and media id with the alter. |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
```yaml
type: automation
trigger:
  - platform: state
    entity: '{{ door_sensor }}'
    to: 'on'
    for: '{{ open_duration }}'
action:
  - service: media_player.play_media
    target:
      entity_id: '{{ alert_media.media_player }}'
    data:
      media_content_id: '{{ alert_media.media_id }}'
variables:
  door_sensor:
    name: Door Sensor
    description: The binary sensor entity for the door.
    selector:
      entity:
        domain: binary_sensor
        device_class: door
  alert_media:
    name: Alert Media
    description: The media player to play the sound and the ID of the file.
    selector:
      media:
        media_player: entity
        media_id: text
  open_duration:
    name: Open Duration
    description: The time the door must remain open.
    selector:
      duration:
mode: single
```
label: Bad
details: AssertionError: Blueprint yaml did not contain 'blueprint:' key

text:
# Door left open

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Play an message on the living room speaker if the garage door has been left open for more than 30 minutes
- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input           | Selector Type | Description                                                                           |
| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | A `binary_sensor` entity selector door sensor that is the target of the automation.   |
| `alert_media`   | `media`       | The target for the `media` selector for the media player and media id with the alter. |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
```yaml
blueprints:
  - alias: 'Alert when door is left open'
    description: 'Plays an alert on the media player when a door sensor has been in the 'on' state for a specified duration.'
    variables:
      door_sensor:
        name: Door Sensor
        description: The binary sensor entity that indicates the door is open.
        selector:
          entity:
            domain: binary_sensor
      alert_media:
        name: Alert Media
        description: The media player entity and the media content ID to play.
        selector:
          media:
      open_duration:
        name: Duration
        description: The amount of time the door must remain open before alerting.
        selector:
          duration:
    trigger:
      - platform: state
        entity_id: '{{ variables.door_sensor }}'
        to: 'on'
        for: '{{ variables.open_duration }}'
    action:
      - service: media_player.play_media
        target:
          entity_id: '{{ variables.alert_media.entity_id }}'
        data:
          media_content_id: '{{ variables.alert_media.media_content_id }}'
    mode: single
```
label: Bad
details: AssertionError: Blueprint yaml did not contain 'blueprint:' key

text:
# Door left open

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Play an message on the living room speaker if the garage door has been left open for more than 30 minutes
- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input           | Selector Type | Description                                                                           |
| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | A `binary_sensor` entity selector door sensor that is the target of the automation.   |
| `alert_media`   | `media`       | The target for the `media` selector for the media player and media id with the alter. |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
```yaml
blueprint:
  name: Door Left Open Alert
  description: Play an alert on the speaker when the door is left open.
  domain: automation
  input:
    door_sensor:
      name: Door Sensor
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: binary_sensor
    alert_media:
      name: Alert Media
      selector:
        media:
    open_duration:
      name: Open Duration
      selector:
        duration:

  trigger:
    - platform: state
      entity_id: !input door_sensor
      to: 'on'

  condition:
    - condition: template
      value_template: '{{ states[!input door_sensor].state == 'on' }}'

  action:
    - delay: !input open_duration
    - service: media_player.play_media
      data:
        entity_id: !input alert_media.entity_id
        media_content_id: !input alert_media.media_id
```
label: Good

# Door left open

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Play an message on the living room speaker if the garage door has been left open for more than 30 minutes
- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input           | Selector Type | Description                                                                           |
| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | A `binary_sensor` entity selector door sensor that is the target of the automation.   |
| `alert_media`   | `media`       | The target for the `media` selector for the media player and media id with the alter. |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
```yaml
blueprints:
  - name: 'Alert when door left open'
    domain: automation

    input_selectors:
      door_sensor:
        entity:
          domain: binary_sensor
          device_class: door
      alert_media:
        media:
          domain: media_player
      media_content_id:
        text:
          default: 'sound.alert'
      open_duration:
        duration:
          default: '00:30:00'

    automation:
      trigger:
        - platform: state
          entity_id: input_selectors.door_sensor
          to: 'on'
          for: '{{ open_duration }}'

      action:
        - service: media_player.play_media
          target:
            entity_id: '{{ alert_media }}'
          data:
            media_content_id: '{{ media_content_id }}'
```
label: Bad
details: AssertionError: Blueprint yaml did not contain 'blueprint:' key

# Door left open

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |

| `alert_media`   | `media`       | The target for the `media` selector for the media player and media id with the alter. |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
```yaml
blueprints:
  id: 'door_left_open_alert'
  name: 'Door Left Open Alert'
  domain: automation

  input:
    door_sensor:
      name: Door Sensor
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: binary_sensor

    alert_media:
      name: Alert Media
      description: Select the media player and the specific media ID to play.
      selector:
        media:
          media_player: []
          media_id: ''

    open_duration:
      name: Open Duration
      description: Time the door must remain open before the alert plays.
      selector:
        duration: {}

  trigger:
    - platform: state
        entity_id: !input door_sensor
        to: 'on'
        for: !input open_duration

  action:
    - service: media_player.play_media
      target:
        entity_id: !input alert_media.media_player
      data:
        media_content_id: !input alert_media.media_id
        media_content_type: audio

  mode: single
```
label: Bad
details: ^,AssertionError: Blueprint was not valid yaml: mapping values are not allowed here   in '<unicode string>', line 29, column 18:             entity_id: !input door_sensor                      ^

text:
# Door left open

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Play an message on the living room speaker if the garage door has been left open for more than 30 minutes
- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input           | Selector Type | Description                                                                           |
| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | A `binary_sensor` entity selector door sensor that is the target of the automation.   |
| `alert_media`   | `media`       | The target for the `media` selector for the media player and media id with the alter. |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
```yaml
blueprint:
  name: Door left open alert
  description: |
    Plays a chosen audio message on a media player when a door sensor has been
    in the 'on' state for a specified duration.
  domain: automation
  input:
    door_sensor:
      name: Door sensor
      description: Binary sensor that reports the door state.
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: binary_sensor
    alert_media:
      name: Alert media
      description: Media to play on the chosen media player.
      selector:
        media:
    open_duration:
      name: Open duration
      description: Time the door must remain open before the alert is triggered.
      selector:
        duration:

trigger:
  # Trigger when the door stays open for the specified duration
  - platform: state
    entity_id: !input door_sensor
    to: 'on'
    for: !input open_duration

action:
  - service: media_player.play_media
    data_template:
      # The media selector returns an object that contains the media_player
      # entity and the media content to play.  The template pulls those
      # values out of the selector.
      entity_id: '{{ alert_media.media_player.entity_id }}'
      media_content_id: '{{ alert_media.media_id }}'
      media_content_type: '{{ alert_media.media_type }}'
```
label: Good

text:
# Door left open

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Play an message on the living room speaker if the garage door has been left open for more than 30 minutes
- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input           | Selector Type | Description                                                                           |
| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | A `binary_sensor` entity selector door sensor that is the target of the automation.   |
| `alert_media`   | `media`       | The target for the `media` selector for the media player and media id with the alter. |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
**Blueprint – Door left open alert**

```yaml
blueprint:
  name: Door left open alert
  domain: automation
  description: >
    Plays a selected media when a binary sensor (door) has been
    open for a specified duration.
  input:
    door_sensor:
      name: Door sensor
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: binary_sensor
    alert_media:
      name: Media to play
      selector:
        media:
    open_duration:
      name: Open duration
      selector:
        duration:

trigger:
  - platform: state
    entity_id: !input door_sensor
    to: 'on'
    for: !input open_duration

action:
  - service: media_player.play_media
    data:
      entity_id: !input alert_media
      media_content_id: !input alert_media
      media_content_type: music
```

**How it works**

1. **Trigger** – When the selected `door_sensor` turns *on* (open) and stays open for the duration defined by `open_duration`, the trigger fires.
2. **Action** – The automation calls `media_player.play_media` on the media player chosen in `alert_media`.  
   The media ID selected in the media selector is used as the content to play.  

You can customize the `open_duration` for each door, and pick any media (e.g., a pre‑recorded alert or a text‑to‑speech message) from your media library.
label: Good

```yaml
      name: Media to play
      selector:
        media:
    open_duration:
      name: Open duration
      selector:
        duration:

trigger:
  - platform: state
    entity_id: !input door_sensor
    to: 'on'
    for: !input open_duration

action:
  - service: media_player.play_media
    data:
      entity_id: !input alert_media
      media_content_id: !input alert_media
      media_content_type: music
```

**How it works**

1. **Trigger** – When the selected `door_sensor` turns *on* (open) and stays open for the duration defined by `open_duration`, the trigger fires.
2. **Action** – The automation calls `media_player.play_media` on the media player chosen in `alert_media`.  
   The media ID selected in the media selector is used as the content to play.  

You can customize the `open_duration` for each door, and pick any media (e.g., a pre‑recorded alert or a text‑to‑speech message) from your media library.

text:
# Door left open

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Play an message on the living room speaker if the garage door has been left open for more than 30 minutes
- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input           | Selector Type | Description                                                                           |
| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | A `binary_sensor` entity selector door sensor that is the target of the automation.   |
| `alert_media`   | `media`       | The target for the `media` selector for the media player and media id with the alter. |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
Here is a Home‑Assistant automation blueprint that will play a chosen media file on a media player when a door sensor has been open for a user‑defined amount of time.

```yaml
blueprint:
  name: Door left open alert
  description: |
    Play a selected media file on a media player when a door (or any binary
    sensor) has been in the *on* state for a specified duration.
  domain: automation
  source_url: https://github.com/yourrepo/door-alert-blueprint

  # Inputs the blueprint needs from the user
  input:
    door_sensor:
      name: Door sensor
      description: Binary sensor that indicates the door is open (on) or closed (off)
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: binary_sensor
    alert_media:
      name: Alert media
      description: |
        Media player and media id to play when the door is left open.
        The media selector allows you to pick a player and a media file.
      selector:
        media:
          media_class: music      # or audio, video, etc. as needed
    open_duration:
      name: Open duration
      description: |
        How long the door must stay open before the alert is played.
      selector:
        duration:
          min: 0
          max: 24:00:00
          default: 00:30:00  # 30 minutes by default

trigger:
  - platform: state
    entity_id: !input door_sensor
    to: 'on'
    for: !input open_duration

action:
  - service: media_player.play_media
    target: !input alert_media
    data:
      # No extra data needed – the media selector already contains
      # entity_id, media_content_id, and media_content_type.
```

### How to use this blueprint

1. **Import the blueprint**  
   In Home Assistant, go to *Configuration → Automations → Import* and paste the above YAML, or drop it into your `blueprints` folder.

2. **Create an automation**  
   In the Automations UI, choose “Create automation from blueprint” and select this one.  
   Provide:
   * The binary sensor that represents your door (e.g., `binary_sensor.garage_door`).
   * The media player and media file you want to play (e.g., a notification file on your living‑room speaker).
   * The time you want to wait before alerting (e.g., `00:05:00` for 5 minutes).

3. **Save** and activate the automation.

When the selected door sensor turns on, the automation will wait for the specified duration. If the door remains open for that entire period, the media file will be played on the chosen media player. If the door closes before the timer expires, no alert will be triggered.
label: Good

text:
# Door left open

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Play an message on the living room speaker if the garage door has been left open for more than 30 minutes
- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input           | Selector Type | Description                                                                           |
| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | A `binary_sensor` entity selector door sensor that is the target of the automation.   |
| `alert_media`   | `media`       | The target for the `media` selector for the media player and media id with the alter. |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
Here’s a **YAML blueprint** for your Home Assistant automation to alert when a door is left open:

```yaml
blueprint:
  name: Door Left Open Alert
  description: >
    Plays an alert on a speaker when a door is left open for a specified duration.
  domain: automation
  input:
    door_sensor:
      name: Door Sensor
      description: The door sensor to monitor.
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: binary_sensor
          device_class: door
    alert_media:
      name: Alert Media
      description: The media player and sound to play when the door is left open.
      selector:
        media:
    open_duration:
      name: Open Duration
      description: How long the door must stay open before triggering the alert.
      selector:
        duration:

  source_url: https://community.home-assistant.io/t/door-left-open-alert-blueprint/123456
```

### **Automation YAML (for use in Home Assistant)**
To use this blueprint, create an automation with this YAML (adjust inputs as needed):

```yaml
alias: 'Door Left Open Alert'
description: 'Alerts when a door is left open for too long'
trigger:
  - platform: state
    entity_id: !input door_sensor
    to: 'on'
action:
  - delay: !input open_duration
  - if:
      condition: state
      entity_id: !input door_sensor
      state: 'on'
    then:
      - service: media_player.play_media
        target: !input alert_media
        data:
          media_content_type: 'sound'
          media_content_id: !input alert_media
```

### **How It Works**
1. **Trigger:** Monitors the door sensor for an open state.
2. **Delay:** Waits for the specified duration (`open_duration`).
3. **Check:** If the door is still open after the delay, it plays the alert on the selected media player.

### **Example Use Case (Garage Door)**
```yaml
alias: 'Garage Door Left Open Alert'
description: 'Alerts if garage door is open for >30 minutes'
use_blueprint:
  path: your_blueprint_path.yaml  # Replace with actual path
  input:
    door_sensor: binary_sensor.garage_door
    alert_media: media_player.living_room
    open_duration: '00:30:00'
```

### **Notes**
- Replace `your_blueprint_path.yaml` with the actual path where you save the blueprint.
- Ensure the `door_sensor` is a **binary_sensor** with `device_class: door`.
- The `alert_media` should be a **media player** with a valid sound file (e.g., `media_content_id: /local/alert.mp3`).
label: Bad
details: AssertionError: Blueprint yaml did not contain 'blueprint:' key

```yaml
blueprint:
  name: Door Left Open Alert
  description: >
    Plays an alert on a speaker when a door is left open for a specified duration.
```
```yaml
    Example use cases:
    - Play a message on the living room speaker if the garage door is open for >30 minutes.
    - Alert on the kitchen speaker if the front door is ajar for >5 minutes.
  domain: automation
  input:
    door_sensor:
      name: Door Sensor

mode: single
max_exceeded: silent

trigger:
  - platform: state
    entity_id: !input door_sensor
    to: 'on'

action:
  - delay: !input open_duration
  - if:
      condition: state
      entity_id: !input door_sensor
```

text:
# Door left open

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Play an message on the living room speaker if the garage door has been left open for more than 30 minutes
- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input           | Selector Type | Description                                                                           |
| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | A `binary_sensor` entity selector door sensor that is the target of the automation.   |
| `alert_media`   | `media`       | The target for the `media` selector for the media player and media id with the alter. |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
Here’s a simple blueprint for your automation:

### **Automation Blueprint**
```yaml
alias: 'Play Alert When Door Left Open'
description: 'Play an alert when a door is left open for too long.'
trigger:
  - platform: state
    entity_id: '{{ door_sensor }}'
    to: 'open'
    for:
      seconds: '{{ open_duration }}'
action:
  - service: media_player.play_media
    target:
      entity_id: '{{ alert_media }}'
    data:
      media_type: 'music'
      media_url: ''  # Replace with your alert sound file path if needed
      volume_level: 0.7  # Optional: Adjust volume
mode: single
```

### **How to Use:**
1. **Set up inputs** in your `configuration.yaml`:
   ```yaml
   input_select:
     door_sensor:
       options:
         - binary_sensor.garage_door
         - binary_sensor.front_door
       default: binary_sensor.garage_door
     alert_media:
       options:
         - media_player.living_room_speaker
         - media_player.kitchen_speaker
       default: media_player.living_room_speaker
     open_duration:
       options:
         - 30
         - 5
       default: 30
   ```

2. **Trigger the automation** via the UI or CLI with:
   ```bash
   /config/automation/trigger --entity_id door_sensor --to open --duration 30
   ```

### **Notes:**
- Replace `binary_sensor.garage_door` with your actual door sensor.
- Replace `media_player.living_room_speaker` with your speaker entity.
- For a custom alert sound, use a file path (e.g., `media://alert.mp3`).
label: Bad
details: AssertionError: Blueprint yaml did not contain 'blueprint:' key

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Play an message on the living room speaker if the garage door has been left open for more than 30 minutes
- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input           | Selector Type | Description                                                                           |
| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | A `binary_sensor` entity selector door sensor that is the target of the automation.   |
| `alert_media`   | `media`       | The target for the `media` selector for the media player and media id with the alter. |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
Here’s a simple blueprint for your automation:

### **Automation Blueprint**
```yaml
alias: 'Play Alert When Door Left Open'
```
```yaml
description: 'Plays an alert when a door is left open for a specified duration.'
trigger:
  - platform: state
    entity_id: '{{ door_sensor }}'
    to: 'open'
    for:
      hours: 0
      minutes: '{{ open_duration.split(':')[0] }}'
      seconds: '{{ open_duration.split(':')[1] if open_duration.count(':') > 0 else '0' }}'
action:
  - service: media_player.play_media
    target:
      entity_id: '{{ alert_media }}'
    data:
      media_type: 'music'
      media_url: ''  # Replace with your alert sound file path or use a service like `media_player.play_media` with a predefined alert
      volume_level: 0.7  # Adjust volume as needed
mode: single
```

---

### **How to Use:**
1. **Replace placeholders** with your actual entities:
   - `door_sensor`: Your binary sensor (e.g., `binary_sensor.garage_door`).
   - `alert_media`: Your media player (e.g., `media_player.living_room_speaker`).
   - `open_duration`: The time threshold (e.g., `00:30` for 30 minutes).

2. **Alternative for Alert Sound**:
   Use a predefined alert sound (e.g., a `.mp3` file) or a service like:
   ```yaml
   service: media_player.play_media
   target:
     entity_id: '{{ alert_media }}'
   data:
     media_type: 'music'
     media_url: 'file:///path/to/alert_sound.mp3'
   ```

3. **Test & Debug**:
   - Use `logger.log` to check if the trigger fires:
     ```yaml
     action:
       - service: logger.log
         data:
           message: 'Door open for {{ open_duration }}!'
     ```

---
### **Notes**:
- Ensure the door sensor is in `open` state for the duration.
- Adjust `volume_level` or use a different media player method if needed.

# Door left open

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Play an message on the living room speaker if the garage door has been left open for more than 30 minutes
- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input           | Selector Type | Description                                                                           |
| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | A `binary_sensor` entity selector door sensor that is the target of the automation.   |
| `alert_media`   | `media`       | The target for the `media` selector for the media player and media id with the alter. |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
Here’s a simple automation blueprint for your use case:

### **Automation Blueprint**
```yaml
alias: 'Play Alert When Door Left Open'
description: 'Plays an alert when a door is left open for too long.'
trigger:
  - platform: state
    entity_id: '{{ input_select.door_sensor }}'
    to: 'open'
    for:
      minutes: '{{ input_duration.open_duration | int / 60 }}'
mode: single

action:
  - service: media_player.play_media
    target:
      entity_id: '{{ input_media.alert_media }}'
    data:
      media_type: 'music'
      media_title: 'Door Open Alert'
      media_id: 'your_alert_sound_file'  # Replace with actual media ID or file path
    data_template:
      volume_level: '{{ state_attr('media_player', 'volume_level') | default(0.7) }}'

condition:
  - condition: state
    entity_id: '{{ input_select.door_sensor }}'
    state: 'open'
```

### **How to Use:**
1. **Inputs:**
   - `door_sensor`: Replace with your door sensor entity ID (e.g., `binary_sensor.garage_door`).
   - `alert_media`: Replace with your speaker entity ID (e.g., `media_player.living_room_speaker`) and media ID (e.g., a sound file or URL).
   - `open_duration`: Set the time (e.g., `30` for 30 minutes).

2. **How it works:**
   - Triggers when the door state changes to 'open' for the specified duration.
   - Plays the alert on the selected speaker.

### **Notes:**
- Ensure your door sensor supports `state` triggers.
- Adjust `media_type` and `media_title` as needed.
- For a sound file, use a URL or local file path (e.g., `media_id: 'file:///path/to/sound.mp3'`).

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
Here’s a simple **Home Assistant Blueprint** for your door-open alert automation:

---
### **Blueprint: Door Left Open Alert**
**Name:** Door Left Open Alert
**Description:** Plays an alert on a speaker when a door is left open for a specified duration.

#### **Inputs:**
| Input           | Selector Type | Required | Default | Description                                  |
|-----------------|---------------|----------|---------|----------------------------------------------|
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | Yes      |         | Binary sensor (e.g., `binary_sensor.garage_door`) |
| `alert_media`   | `media`       | Yes      |         | Media player + media ID (e.g., `media_player.living_room: 'door_alert.mp3'`) |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | Yes      | `00:30:00` | Time before triggering (e.g., `00:05:00` for 5 mins) |

---

### **YAML Code:**
```yaml
alias: 'Door Left Open Alert'
description: 'Triggers an alert when a door is left open for a specified duration.'
trigger:
  - platform: state
    entity_id: !input door_sensor
    to: 'on'
    for:
      hours: !input open_duration.hours
      minutes: !input open_duration.minutes
      seconds: !input open_duration.seconds
action:
  - service: media_player.play_media
    target:
      entity_id: !input alert_media.entity_id
    data:
      media_content_id: !input alert_media.media_id
      media_content_type: 'uri'
mode: single
```

---

### **How to Use:**
1. **Add the Blueprint** in Home Assistant via **Settings > Automations & Scenes > Blueprints > Import**.
2. **Configure Inputs**:
   - `door_sensor`: Select your binary sensor (e.g., `binary_sensor.garage_door`).
   - `alert_media`: Choose a speaker (e.g., `media_player.living_room`) and a sound file (e.g., `door_alert.mp3`).
   - `open_duration`: Set how long the door must stay open (e.g., `00:05:00` for 5 minutes).
3. **Save & Enable** the automation.

---
### **Notes:**
- Ensure your binary sensor reports `on` when the door is open.
- The media file must exist in your Home Assistant media directory or be accessible via a URL.
- Adjust `open_duration` in the YAML if needed (e.g., `hours: 0, minutes: 5`).

# Door left open

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Play an message on the living room speaker if the garage door has been left open for more than 30 minutes
- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input           | Selector Type | Description                                                                           |
| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | A `binary_sensor` entity selector door sensor that is the target of the automation.   |
| `alert_media`   | `media`       | The target for the `media` selector for the media player and media id with the alter. |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
Here’s a simple **Home Assistant Blueprint** for your door-open alert automation:

---
**Name:** Door Left Open Alert
**Description:** Plays an alert on a speaker when a door is left open for a specified duration.

**Inputs:**
| **Input**         | **Type**      | **Description**                                                                 |
|-------------------|---------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| `door_sensor`     | `entity`      | Binary sensor (e.g., `binary_sensor.garage_door`) that detects the door state. |
| `alert_media`     | `media`       | Media player (e.g., `media_player.living_room`) and media ID (e.g., `alert.mp3`). |
| `open_duration`   | `duration`    | Time (e.g., `00:30:00`) before triggering the alert.                          |

---
### **Automation Code:**
```yaml
alias: 'Door Left Open Alert'
description: 'Triggers an alert when a door is left open for a specified duration.'
trigger:
  - platform: state
    entity_id: !input door_sensor
    to: 'on'
action:
  - delay: !input open_duration
  - if:
      - condition: state
        entity_id: !input door_sensor
        state: 'on'
    then:
      - service: media_player.play_media
        target:
          entity_id: !input alert_media
        data:
          media_content_id: !input alert_media
          media_content_type: 'uri'
```

---
### **How It Works:**
1. **Trigger:** Detects when the door sensor turns `on`.
2. **Delay:** Waits for the specified duration (`open_duration`).
3. **Check:** Verifies the door is still open before playing the alert.
4. **Alert:** Plays the selected media on the target speaker.

---
### **Example Setup:**
- **Door Sensor:** `binary_sensor.garage_door`
- **Media Player:** `media_player.living_room`
- **Media ID:** `alert.mp3` (or a sound notification like `notify.alert`)
- **Duration:** `00:30:00` (30 minutes)

---
### **Notes:**
- Ensure the `alert_media` input includes **both** the player and media ID (e.g., `media_player.living_room:alert.mp3`).
- For notifications, replace `media_player.play_media` with `notify.notify` (if using a notification service).
label: Bad
details: AssertionError: Blueprint yaml did not contain 'blueprint:' key

# Door left open

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Play an message on the living room speaker if the garage door has been left open for more than 30 minutes
- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input           | Selector Type | Description                                                                           |
| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | A `binary_sensor` entity selector door sensor that is the target of the automation.   |

| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.

text:
# Door left open

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Play an message on the living room speaker if the garage door has been left open for more than 30 minutes
- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input           | Selector Type | Description                                                                           |
| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | A `binary_sensor` entity selector door sensor that is the target of the automation.   |
| `alert_media`   | `media`       | The target for the `media` selector for the media player and media id with the alter. |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
I can't create a blueprint automation directly, as that requires access to Home Assistant's automation editor. However, I can help you write the YAML configuration for such an automation based on your requirements.

Here’s a sample automation configuration you can use in Home Assistant:

```yaml
automation:
  - alias: 'Play Alert if Door Left Open'
    description: 'Plays a media alert if a door is left open for a specified duration.'
    trigger:
      - platform: state
        entity_id: '{{ door_sensor }}'
        to: 'on'
        from: 'off'
        for:
          minutes: '{{ open_duration }}'
    action:
      - service: media_player.play_media
        target:
          entity_id: '{{ alert_media }}'
        data:
          media_content_id: '{{ alert_media }}'
          media_content_type: 'music'
```

### How to Use:
1. Replace `{{ door_sensor }}` with the actual entity ID of your door sensor (e.g., `binary_sensor.entry_door`).
2. Replace `{{ alert_media }}` with the media player entity ID (e.g., `media_player.living_room_speaker`).
3. Replace `{{ open_duration }}` with the desired duration in minutes (e.g., `5` for 5 minutes).

### Example:
If you want to play a sound on the living room speaker when the front door is open for 5 minutes:

```yaml
trigger:
  - platform: state
    entity_id: binary_sensor.entry_door
    to: 'on'
    from: 'off'
    for:
      minutes: 5
action:
  - service: media_player.play_media
    target:
      entity_id: media_player.smart_speaker
    data:
      media_content_id: 'alert_door_open.mp3'
      media_content_type: 'music'
```

> 💡 Tip: You can upload your alert audio file to Home Assistant (e.g., via the `media` folder) and reference it by filename.

Let me know if you'd like help creating a specific version for your setup!
label: Bad
details: AssertionError: Blueprint yaml did not contain 'blueprint:' key

# Door left open

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Play an message on the living room speaker if the garage door has been left open for more than 30 minutes
- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input           | Selector Type | Description                                                                           |
| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | A `binary_sensor` entity selector door sensor that is the target of the automation.   |
| `alert_media`   | `media`       | The target for the `media` selector for the media player and media id with the alter. |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
I cannot create or modify blueprints directly. However, I can guide you on how to create the automation using the Home Assistant UI.

1. Go to **Configuration** in your Home Assistant dashboard.
2. Select **Automations & Scenes**.
3. Click on **Create Automation**.
4. Choose **Blueprint** and select **Create from scratch**.
5. Add the following inputs to your blueprint:
   - `door_sensor`: Select a `binary_sensor` entity for the door sensor.
   - `alert_media`: Select the media to play using the `media` selector.
   - `open_duration`: Set the amount of time the door must be open before playing the alert using the `duration` selector.
6. Set the trigger to monitor the `door_sensor` for the state `on` (indicating the door is open).
7. Add a condition to check if the door has been open for the specified `open_duration`.
8. Add an action to play the selected `alert_media` on the specified media player.

Here’s an example of how the blueprint might look in YAML format:

```yaml
blueprint:
  name: Door Left Open Alert
  description: Play an alert when a door is left open for a specified duration.
  inputs:
    door_sensor:
      name: Door Sensor
      description: The binary sensor to monitor.
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: binary_sensor
    alert_media:
      name: Alert Media
      description: The media to play when the alert is triggered.
      selector:
        media:
          domain: media_player
    open_duration:
      name: Open Duration
      description: The amount of time the door must be open before playing the alert.
      selector:
        duration:
          enable: true

trigger:
  - platform: state
    entity_id: !input door_sensor
    to: 'on'

condition:
  - condition: state
    entity_id: !input door_sensor
    state: 'on'
    for:
      minutes: !input open_duration

action:
  - service: media_player.play_media
    data:
      entity_id: !input alert_media
      media_content_id: 'https://example.com/alert.mp3'
      media_content_type: 'music'
```

This blueprint will play the specified alert media when the door has been open for the specified duration. You can customize the alert media and other parameters as needed.

text:
# Door left open

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Play an message on the living room speaker if the garage door has been left open for more than 30 minutes
- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input           | Selector Type | Description                                                                           |
| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | A `binary_sensor` entity selector door sensor that is the target of the automation.   |
| `alert_media`   | `media`       | The target for the `media` selector for the media player and media id with the alter. |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
Here's a blueprint automation that plays an alert on a speaker when a door has been left open for a specified duration:

```yaml
blueprint:
  name: 'Door Left Open Alert'
  description: 'Plays an alert on a media player when a door has been left open for a specified duration.'
  input:
    door_sensor:
      name: 'Door Sensor'
      description: 'The binary sensor that detects if the door is open.'
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: binary_sensor
    alert_media:
      name: 'Alert Media'
      description: 'The media to play when the door is left open for the specified duration.'
      selector:
        media:
          domain: media_player
    open_duration:
      name: 'Open Duration'
      description: 'The amount of time the door needs to be open before playing the alert.'
      selector:
        duration:
          min: 1
          max: 1440
          step: 1
          unit: minutes

automations:
  - alias: 'Door Left Open Alert'
    trigger:
      - platform: state
        entity_id: !input door_sensor
        to: 'on'
    condition:
      - condition: state
        entity_id: !input door_sensor
        state: 'on'
        for:
          minutes: !input open_duration
    action:
      - service: media_player.play_media
        target:
          entity_id: !input alert_media
        data:
          media_content_id: 'https://your-alert-sound.mp3'
          media_content_type: 'music'
```

In this blueprint:

- `door_sensor` is the binary sensor that detects if the door is open.
- `alert_media` is the media player and media ID for the alert sound.
- `open_duration` is the duration the door must be open before the alert is played.

The automation is triggered when the door sensor changes to an 'on' state (indicating the door is open). It then checks if the door has been open for the specified duration. If so, it plays the alert sound on the specified media player.

You can customize the `media_content_id` to point to your desired alert sound.
label: Good

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
I can guide you on how to create a blueprint automation in Home Assistant for this scenario. Here's how you can do it:

1. **Open the Automation Editor**:
   - Go to the Home Assistant app or website.
   - Navigate to 'Configuration' > 'Devices & Services' > 'Automation & Scenes'.

2. **Create a New Automation**:
   - Click on the '+' icon to create a new automation.
   - Select 'Blueprint' as the automation type.

3. **Define Inputs**:
   - In the blueprint editor, define the following inputs:
     - **`door_sensor`**: A binary sensor entity that represents the door sensor.
     - **`alert_media`**: The media to play (e.g., a sound file or a message).
     - **`open_duration`**: The duration the door must be open before triggering the alert.

4. **Trigger**:
   - Add a trigger for the door sensor being open. You can use the 'State' trigger and set the condition to 'is open'.

5. **Condition**:
   - Add a condition to check if the door has been open for the specified duration. Use the 'Time' condition and set the duration to the value provided in the `open_duration` input.

6. **Action**:
   - Add an action to play the selected media on the specified media player. You can use the `media_player.play_media` service and provide the media ID and media player entity as inputs.

7. **Save and Test**:
   - Save the automation and test it by leaving the door open for the specified duration.

Here's a sample YAML configuration for the blueprint automation:

```yaml
blueprint:
  name: Door Open Alert
  description: Plays an alert on the speaker when the door is left open for a specified duration.
  inputs:
    door_sensor:
      name: Door Sensor
      description: The binary sensor entity for the door.
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: binary_sensor
    alert_media:
      name: Alert Media
      description: The media to play when the door is left open.
      selector:
        media:
          entity:
            domain: media_player
    open_duration:
      name: Open Duration
      description: The duration the door must be open before playing the alert.
      selector:
        duration:

trigger:
  - platform: state
    entity_id: !input door_sensor
    to: 'on'

condition:
  - condition: time
    seconds: !input open_duration

action:
  - service: media_player.play_media
    target:
      entity_id: !input alert_media
    data:
      media_content_id: 'https://example.com/alert.mp3'
      media_content_type: 'music'
```

This blueprint automation will play an alert on the specified media player when the door has been left open for the specified duration. You can customize the media content ID to use your own alert sound file.

text:
# Door left open

## Problem statement

Create an blueprint automation to play an alert on the speaker when the door is
left open.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Play an message on the living room speaker if the garage door has been left open for more than 30 minutes
- When the front door is ajar for 5 minutes, play a sound on the kitchen bluetooth speaker.

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input           | Selector Type | Description                                                                           |
| --------------- | ------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `door_sensor`   | `entity`      | A `binary_sensor` entity selector door sensor that is the target of the automation.   |
| `alert_media`   | `media`       | The target for the `media` selector for the media player and media id with the alter. |
| `open_duration` | `duration`    | A `duration` selector, the amount of time before playing the alert.                   |

The automation should play the selected media when the door has been open for the specified duration.
response:
Here is a blueprint automation that plays an alert on the speaker when a door has been left open for a specified duration:

```yaml
blueprint:
  name: Play alert if door is left open
  description: Plays an alert on a speaker if a door has been left open for a specified duration.
  domain: automation
  inputs:
    - name: door_sensor
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: binary_sensor
          device_class: door
    - name: alert_media
      selector:
        media:
          domain: media_player
    - name: open_duration
      selector:
        duration:
          min: 00:01:00
          max: 23:59:59
```

```yaml
- alias: Play alert if door is left open
  description: Plays an alert on a speaker if a door has been left open for a specified duration.
  trigger:
    - platform: state
      entity_id: !input door_sensor
      to: 'on'
  condition:
    - condition: template
      value_template: '{{ (as_timestamp(now()) - as_timestamp(states.binary_sensor.is_open.last_updated)) >= (input.open_duration.total_seconds()) }}'
  action:
    - service: media_player.play_media
      target:
        entity_id: !input alert_media
      data:
        media_content_type: 'url'
        media_content_id: 'https://example.com/alert.mp3'
```

This automation will trigger when the door sensor changes to 'on' (indicating that the door is open). It will then check if the door has been open for the specified duration using a template condition. If the condition is met, it will play the selected media on the specified media player. You can replace the URL with the actual URL of the alert you want to play.

```yaml
  name: 'Door Left Open Alert'
  description: 'Plays an alert on a media player when a door has been left open for a specified duration.'
  domain: automation
  input:
    door_sensor:
      name: 'Door Sensor'
      description: 'The binary sensor that detects the door state.'
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: binary_sensor
    alert_media:
      name: 'Alert Media'
      description: 'The media to play on the media player when the alert is triggered.'
      selector:
        media:
          domain: media_player
    open_duration:
      name: 'Open Duration'
      description: 'The duration the door must be open before the alert is triggered.'
      selector:
        duration: {}
  variables:
    door_sensor: !input door_sensor
    alert_media: !input alert_media
    open_duration: !input open_duration

trigger:
  - platform: state
    entity_id: !input door_sensor
    to: 'on'
    for:
      minutes: !input open_duration
      seconds: 0

action:
  - service: media_player.play_media
    target:
      entity_id: !input alert_media
    data:
      media_content_id: 'https://example.com/alert.mp3'
      media_content_type: 'music'
```

### Explanation:

1. **Inputs**:
   - `door_sensor`: This is the binary sensor that detects whether the door is open (`on`) or closed (`off`).
   - `alert_media`: This is the media player entity where the alert will be played.
   - `open_duration`: This is the duration the door must be open before the alert is triggered.

2. **Trigger**:
   - The automation is triggered when the `door_sensor` changes to `on` and stays that way for the specified `open_duration`.

3. **Action**:
   - The action uses the `media_player.play_media` service to play the alert media on the specified `alert_media` entity.
   - Replace `'https://example.com/alert.mp3'` with the actual URL or path to your alert sound.

### Example Use Cases:

- **Garage Door Alert**:
  - Set `door_sensor` to your garage door binary sensor.
  - Set `alert_media` to your living room speaker.
  - Set `open_duration` to 30 minutes.

- **Front Door Alert**:
  - Set `door_sensor` to your front door binary sensor.
  - Set `alert_media` to your kitchen Bluetooth speaker.
  - Set `open_duration` to 5 minutes.

This blueprint will help you monitor doors and provide timely alerts when they are left open for too long.
label: Good

text:
# Humidity Fan

## Problem statement

Create a blueprint automation to turn on the fan based on the value of the humidity sensor.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Turn on the bathroom exhaust fan when the bathroom humidty is above 60%
- Make sure the garage does not get too humid

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input               | Description                                                           |
| ------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `humidity_sensor` | A `sensor` entity that is a humidty sensor that triggers the automation. |
| `humidity_level` | A `number` selector to set the value used as the trigger. |
| `fan_entity`     | A `fan` entity to turn on when the automation fires. |

The automation should trigger when the `humidity_sensor` level goes above `humidity_level`. When
triggered, the fan should be turned off. The fan should also be stopped when the
sensor goes back down below the desired level. The automation should not try to
turn the fan on if it is already on, and should not turn the fan off when it is
already off.
response:
```yaml
blueprints:
  id: 'humidity_fan_control'
  name: 'Humidity Fan Control'
  domain: automation

trigger:
  - platform: numeric_state
    entity_id: !input humidity_sensor
    above: !input humidity_level

condition:
  - condition: state
    entity_id: !input fan_entity
    state: 'off'

action:
  - service: fan.turn_on
    target:
      entity_id: !input fan_entity

# Block to turn the fan off when humidity drops
- trigger:
    - platform: numeric_state
      entity_id: !input humidity_sensor
      below: !input humidity_level

  condition:
    - condition: state
      entity_id: !input fan_entity
      state: 'on'

  action:
    - service: fan.turn_off
      target:
        entity_id: !input fan_entity

mode: single
```
label: Bad
details: ^,AssertionError: Blueprint was not valid yaml: while parsing a block mapping   in '<unicode string>', line 1, column 1:     blueprints:     ^ expected <block end>, but found '-'   in '<unicode string>', line 22, column 1:     - trigger:     ^

# Humidity Fan

## Problem statement

Create a blueprint automation to turn on the fan based on the value of the humidity sensor.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Turn on the bathroom exhaust fan when the bathroom humidty is above 60%
- Make sure the garage does not get too humid

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input               | Description                                                           |
| ------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `humidity_sensor` | A `sensor` entity that is a humidty sensor that triggers the automation. |
| `humidity_level` | A `number` selector to set the value used as the trigger. |
| `fan_entity`     | A `fan` entity to turn on when the automation fires. |

The automation should trigger when the `humidity_sensor` level goes above `humidity_level`. When
triggered, the fan should be turned off. The fan should also be stopped when the
sensor goes back down below the desired level. The automation should not try to
turn the fan on if it is already on, and should not turn the fan off when it is
already off.
response:
```yaml
blueprints:
  id: 'humidity_fan_control'
  name: 'Humidity Fan Control'
  domain: automation

trigger:
  - platform: numeric_state
    entity_id: !input humidity_sensor
    above: !input humidity_level

condition:
  - condition: state
```

text:
# Humidity Fan

## Problem statement

Create a blueprint automation to turn on the fan based on the value of the humidity sensor.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Turn on the bathroom exhaust fan when the bathroom humidty is above 60%
- Make sure the garage does not get too humid

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input               | Description                                                           |
| ------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `humidity_sensor` | A `sensor` entity that is a humidty sensor that triggers the automation. |
| `humidity_level` | A `number` selector to set the value used as the trigger. |
| `fan_entity`     | A `fan` entity to turn on when the automation fires. |

The automation should trigger when the `humidity_sensor` level goes above `humidity_level`. When
triggered, the fan should be turned off. The fan should also be stopped when the
sensor goes back down below the desired level. The automation should not try to
turn the fan on if it is already on, and should not turn the fan off when it is
already off.
response:
```yaml
blueprint:
  name: Humidity Fan
  description: Automatically turns a fan on when humidity rises above a threshold and off when it drops below.
  domain: automation
  input:
    humidity_sensor:
      name: Humidity Sensor
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: sensor
          device_class: humidity
    humidity_level:
      name: Humidity Level (Threshold)
      selector:
        number:
          mode: slider
          min: 0
          max: 100
          step: 0.5
    fan_entity:
      name: Fan Entity
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: fan

  trigger:
    - platform: numeric_state
      entity_id: !input humidity_sensor
      above: !input humidity_level
    - platform: numeric_state
      entity_id: !input humidity_sensor
      below: !input humidity_level

  action:
    - choose:
        - conditions:
            - condition: numeric_state
              entity_id: !input humidity_sensor
              above: !input humidity_level
          sequence:
            - condition: state
              entity_id: !input fan_entity
              state: off
            - service: fan.turn_on
              target:
                entity_id: !input fan_entity
        - conditions:
            - condition: numeric_state
              entity_id: !input humidity_sensor
              below: !input humidity_level
          sequence:
            - condition: state
              entity_id: !input fan_entity
              state: on
            - service: fan.turn_off
              target:
                entity_id: !input fan_entity
```
label: Good

text:
# Humidity Fan

## Problem statement

Create a blueprint automation to turn on the fan based on the value of the humidity sensor.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Turn on the bathroom exhaust fan when the bathroom humidty is above 60%
- Make sure the garage does not get too humid

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input               | Description                                                           |
| ------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `humidity_sensor` | A `sensor` entity that is a humidty sensor that triggers the automation. |
| `humidity_level` | A `number` selector to set the value used as the trigger. |
| `fan_entity`     | A `fan` entity to turn on when the automation fires. |

The automation should trigger when the `humidity_sensor` level goes above `humidity_level`. When
triggered, the fan should be turned off. The fan should also be stopped when the
sensor goes back down below the desired level. The automation should not try to
turn the fan on if it is already on, and should not turn the fan off when it is
already off.
response:
```yaml
blueprints:
  automation:
    name: Humidity Fan
    variables:
      humidity_sensor: !input 'humidity_sensor'
      humidity_level: !input 'humidity_level'
      fan_entity: !input 'fan_entity'
    trigger:
      - platform: numeric_state
        entity_id: !input 'humidity_sensor'
        above: !input 'humidity_level'
        id: 'humidity_high'
      - platform: numeric_state
        entity_id: !input 'humidity_sensor'
        below: !input 'humidity_level'
        id: 'humidity_low'
    condition:
      - condition: template
        value_template: >
          {% if trigger.id == 'humidity_high' and is_state(fan_entity, 'off') or
             trigger.id == 'humidity_low' and is_state(fan_entity, 'on') %}
            true
          {% else %}
            false
          {% endif %}
    action:
      - service: >
          {% if trigger.id == 'humidity_high' %} fan.turn_on
          {% else %} fan.turn_off
          {% endif %}
        target:
          entity_id: !input 'fan_entity'
    mode: single
```

text:
# Humidity Fan

## Problem statement

Create a blueprint automation to turn on the fan based on the value of the humidity sensor.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Turn on the bathroom exhaust fan when the bathroom humidty is above 60%
- Make sure the garage does not get too humid

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input               | Description                                                           |
| ------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `humidity_sensor` | A `sensor` entity that is a humidty sensor that triggers the automation. |
| `humidity_level` | A `number` selector to set the value used as the trigger. |
| `fan_entity`     | A `fan` entity to turn on when the automation fires. |

The automation should trigger when the `humidity_sensor` level goes above `humidity_level`. When
triggered, the fan should be turned off. The fan should also be stopped when the
sensor goes back down below the desired level. The automation should not try to
turn the fan on if it is already on, and should not turn the fan off when it is
already off.
response:
```yaml
blueprint:
  name: Humidity Controlled Fan
  description: Turns on a fan when humidity rises above a set threshold and turns it off when humidity drops below.
  domain: automation

  input:
    humidity_sensor:
      name: Humidity Sensor
      description: The sensor entity measuring relative humidity.
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: sensor
          filter:
            attributes:
              unit_of_measurement: '%'

    humidity_level:
      name: Humidity Threshold
      description: The humidity level in percentage.
      selector:
        number:
          min: 0
          max: 100
          unit_of_measurement: '%'

    fan_entity:
      name: Fan Entity
      description: The fan to control.
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: fan

  trigger:
    - platform: numeric_state
      entity_id: input.humidity_sensor
      above: input.humidity_level
      id: high

    - platform: numeric_state
      entity_id: input.humidity_sensor
      below: input.humidity_level
      id: low

  condition:
    - condition: template
      value_template: >
        {% if trigger.id == 'high' %}
          {{ is_state('input.fan_entity', 'off') }}
        {% elif trigger.id == 'low' %}
          {{ is_state('input.fan_entity', 'on') }}
        {% else %}
          false
        {% endif %}

  action:
    - service: fan.turn_on
      target:
        entity_id: input.fan_entity
    - service: fan.turn_off
      target:
        entity_id: input.fan_entity
```
label: Good

text:
# Humidity Fan

## Problem statement

Create a blueprint automation to turn on the fan based on the value of the humidity sensor.

## Example use cases

These are example use cases that could be used with the blueprint:

- Turn on the bathroom exhaust fan when the bathroom humidty is above 60%
- Make sure the garage does not get too humid

## Detailed Description

The blueprint should accept two inputs:

| Input               | Description                                                           |
| ------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `humidity_sensor` | A `sensor` entity that is a humidty sensor that triggers the automation. |
| `humidity_level` | A `number` selector to set the value used as the trigger. |
| `fan_entity`     | A `fan` entity to turn on when the automation fires. |

The automation should trigger when the `humidity_sensor` level goes above `humidity_level`. When
triggered, the fan should be turned off. The fan should also be stopped when the
sensor goes back down below the desired level. The automation should not try to
turn the fan on if it is already on, and should not turn the fan off when it is
already off.
response:
**Home Assistant Blueprint – Humidity‑Controlled Fan**

```yaml
blueprint:
  name: Humidity‑Controlled Fan
  description: >
    Turn a fan on when the humidity rises above a set level and turn it off
    again when the humidity falls below that level.  The automation only
    triggers if the fan is actually off/on at the time of the state change
    to avoid unnecessary service calls.
  domain: automation
  input:
    humidity_sensor:
      name: Humidity sensor
      description: Sensor that reports humidity as a percentage
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: sensor
          device_class: humidity
    humidity_level:
      name: Humidity threshold
      description: >-
        When the sensor reading rises above this value the fan will be turned
        on, and when it falls below this value the fan will be turned off.
      selector:
        number:
          min: 0
          max: 100
          unit_of_measurement: '%'
          mode: slider
    fan_entity:
      name: Fan
      description: Fan to be controlled
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: fan

trigger:
  - platform: numeric_state
    entity_id: !input humidity_sensor
    above: !input humidity_level
  - platform: numeric_state
    entity_id: !input humidity_sensor
    below: !input humidity_level

condition:
  # When humidity rises above threshold, only turn on the fan if it is off
  - condition: or
    conditions:
      - condition: and
        conditions:
          - condition: numeric_state
            entity_id: !input humidity_sensor
            above: !input humidity_level
          - condition: state
            entity_id: !input fan_entity
            state: 'off'
      # When humidity falls below threshold, only turn off the fan if it is on
      - condition: and
        conditions:
          - condition: numeric_state
            entity_id: !input humidity_sensor
            below: !input humidity_level
          - condition: state
            entity_id: !input fan_entity
            state: 'on'

action:
  - service: fan.turn_on
    target:
      entity_id: !input fan_entity
    data: {}
    # The action will only be executed when the above condition matches,
    # i.e., when humidity is above threshold and fan is off.
  - service: fan.turn_off
    target:
      entity_id: !input fan_entity
    data: {}
    # The action will only be executed when the below condition matches,
    # i.e., when humidity is below threshold and fan is on.
```

**How it works**

1. Two triggers fire when the humidity sensor crosses the chosen threshold.
2. The condition block checks whether the fan is in the appropriate state
   (off when turning on, on when turning off).
3. Only the matching action (turn on or turn off) is executed, preventing
   redundant service calls.

You can copy this YAML into a new blueprint file (e.g., `humidity_fan.yaml`) and import it into Home Assistant. The automation will then appear in your automations list with the three input fields ready to configure.
label: Good

```yaml
  name: Humidity‑Controlled Fan
  description: >
    Turn a fan on when the humidity rises above a set level and turn it off
    again when the humidity falls below that level.  The automation only
    triggers if the fan is actually off/on at the time of the state change
    to avoid unnecessary service calls.
  domain: automation
  input:
    humidity_sensor:
      name: Humidity sensor
      description: Sensor that reports humidity as a percentage
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: sensor
          device_class: humidity
    humidity_level:
      name: Humidity threshold
      description: >-
        When the sensor reading rises above this value the fan will be turned
        on, and when it falls below this value the fan will be turned off.
      selector:
        number:
          min: 0
          max: 100
          unit_of_measurement: '%'
          mode: slider
    fan_entity:
      name: Fan
      description: Fan to be controlled
      selector:
        entity:
          domain: fan

trigger:
  - platform: numeric_state
    entity_id: !input humidity_sensor
    above: !input humidity_level
  - platform: numeric_state
    entity_id: !input humidity_sensor
    below: !input humidity_level

condition:
  # When humidity rises above threshold, only turn on the fan if it is off
  - condition: or
    conditions:
      - condition: and
        conditions:
          - condition: numeric_state
            entity_id: !input humidity_sensor
            above: !input humidity_level
          - condition: state
            entity_id: !input fan_entity
            state: 'off'
      # When humidity falls below threshold, only turn off the fan if it is on
      - condition: and
        conditions:
          - condition: numeric_state
            entity_id: !input humidity_sensor
            below: !input humidity_level
          - condition: state
            entity_id: !input fan_entity
            state: 'on'

action:
  - service: fan.turn_on
    target:
      entity_id: !input fan_entity
    data: {}
    # The action will only be executed when the above condition matches,
    # i.e., when humidity is above threshold and fan is off.
  - service: fan.turn_off
    target:
      entity_id: !input fan_entity
    data: {}
    # The action will only be executed when the below condition matches,
    # i.e., when humidity is below threshold and fan is on.
```

**How it works**

1. Two triggers fire when the humidity sensor crosses the chosen threshold.
2. The condition block checks whether the fan is in the appropriate state
   (off when turning on, on when turning off).
3. Only the matching action (turn on or turn off) is executed, preventing
   redundant service calls.

You can copy this YAML into a new blueprint file (e.g., `humidity_fan.yaml`) and import it into Home Assistant. The automation will then appear in your automations list with the three input fields ready to configure.
